advalg package¶

Submodules¶

advalg.brute_force module¶

advalg.brute_force.brute_cheapest_hamcycle(g: advalg.graph.Graph) → float¶

Computes the weight of the cheapest hamiltonian cycle in g. Returns inf if no hamiltonian cycle exists.

advalg.brute_force.brute_dnf_count(dnf: advalg.dnf.DNF) → int¶

Uses brute force to count number of satisfying assignments in the given dnf

advalg.brute_force.brute_hamcycles(g: advalg.graph.Graph)¶

Constructs all hamiltonian cycles of g using brute force

advalg.brute_force.brute_isets(g: advalg.graph.Graph) → List[Tuple[int]]¶

Uses brute force to construct all independent sets of g

advalg.brute_force.brute_perf_matchings(g: advalg.graph.Graph) → int¶

Computes the number of perfect matchings in g using brute force.

advalg.brute_force.brute_vc(g: advalg.graph.Graph) → int¶

Computes the size of the minimum vertex cover of g using brute force

advalg.circle module¶

class advalg.circle.Circle(x: float, y: float, radius: float, color)¶

Bases: object

__init__(x: float, y: float, radius: float, color)¶

Construct a circle at position (x,y) with the given radius and color

area() → float¶

Returns the area of the circle

inside(x: float, y: float) → bool¶

Is the point (x,y) inside the circle

advalg.cnf module¶

class advalg.cnf.CNF(var_count)¶

Bases: object

Represents a logical formula in Conjunctive Normal Form

__init__(var_count)¶

Constructs a DNF with variables x1,x2,…,x(var_count)

add_clause(literals: Iterable[int]) → None¶

Add a clause with the given literals. Positive integers correspond to variables and negative integers correspond to negated variables.

clause(i: int) → advalg.cnf.CNFClause¶

Returns the clause with index i

clause_count() → int¶

Returns the number of clauses in the formula

clauses() → List[advalg.cnf.CNFClause]¶

Returns a list with all clauses in the formula

is_satisfied(assignment: Dict[int, bool]) → bool¶

Is this DNF formula satisfied by the given assignment?

var_count() → int¶

Returns the number of variables in the formula

class advalg.cnf.CNFClause(literals: Iterable[int])¶

Bases: object

Represents a clause in a boolean formula in CNF

__init__(literals: Iterable[int])¶

Constructs a clause with the given literals. Positive integers correspond to variables and negative integers correspond to negated variables.

is_satisfied(assignment: Dict[int, bool]) → bool¶

Is the clause satisfied by the given assignment?

advalg.graph module¶

class advalg.graph.Edge(u: int, v: int, w: float)¶

Bases: object

Represents a weighted undirected edge. Has member variables u, v, w for the endpoints and weight respectively.

__init__(u: int, v: int, w: float)¶

Constructs an edge between vertices u and v with weight w

has_endpoint(v: int)¶

Is vertex v an endpoint for this edge?

other(v: int) → int¶

Returns the end point that is not v

class advalg.graph.Graph(n: int = 0)¶

Bases: object

Represents a weighted undirected graph. Vertices are integers in the range [0-n). Loops are permitted but parallel edges are not.

__init__(n: int = 0)¶

Constructs a graph with vertices [0-n) and no edges

add_edge(u: int, v: int, weight: float = 1) → None¶

Add an edge between vertices u and v with the given weight (1 by default)

adj_matrix() → <Mock name='mock.ndarray' id='139848235656912'>¶

Returns the adjacency matrix of the graph

adjacent(v: int) → List[int]¶

Returns a list of vertices adjacent to vertex v

copy() → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Returns a deep copy of the graph

degree(v) → int¶

Returns the degree of vertex v

delete_edge(u: int, v: int) → None¶

Deletes the edge (u,v)

delete_incident(v: int) → None¶

Delete all edges incident with vertex v

edge_count() → int¶

Returns the number of edges in the graph

edge_exists(u: int, v: int) → bool¶

Does the graph contain an edge (u,v)?

edge_weight(u: int, v: int) → float¶

Returns the weight associated with the edge (u,v)

edges() → Iterator[advalg.graph.Edge]¶

Returns all edges in the graph as a generator

static from_file(path: str) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Constructs a graph from a file. First line should be number of vertices. Each remaining line contains an edge u v.

has_vertex(v: int) → bool¶

Is v a vertex in this graph?

incident(v: int) → List[advalg.graph.Edge]¶

Returns a list of edges incident to vertex v

to_file(path: str) → None¶

Writes this graph to a file

vertex_count() → int¶

Returns the number of vertices in the graph

vertices() → Iterator[int]¶

Returns all vertices in the graph as a generator

advalg.graph_helpers module¶

advalg.graph_helpers.is_hamcycle(g: advalg.graph.Graph, tour: List[int]) → bool¶

Is the given tour a hamiltonian cycle in g?

advalg.graph_helpers.is_iset(g: advalg.graph.Graph, s: Iterable[int]) → bool¶

Is s an independent set of graph g?

advalg.graph_helpers.is_perf_matching(g: advalg.graph.Graph, m: List[advalg.graph.Edge]) → bool¶

Is m a perfect matching in the graph g?

advalg.graph_helpers.is_vc(g: advalg.graph.Graph, vc: Iterable[int]) → bool¶

Is vc a vertex cover of the graph g?

advalg.graph_helpers.make_clique(n: int) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Constructs a clique with n vertices

advalg.graph_helpers.make_cycle(n: int) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Constructs of cycle with n vertices. A cycle with 0 vertices is the empty graph. A cycle with 1 vertex is a loop. A cycle with 2 vertices is not permitted because of parallel edges.

advalg.graph_helpers.make_grid(rows: int, cols: int) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Constructs a grid graph with the given rows and columns

advalg.graph_helpers.make_path(n: int) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Constructs a path with n vertices (n-1 edges)

advalg.graph_helpers.make_random(n: int, p: float) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Constructs a random graph where each edge is sampled with probability p

advalg.graph_helpers.random() → x in the interval [0, 1).¶
advalg.graph_helpers.tour_cost(g: advalg.graph.Graph, tour: List[int]) → float¶

Returns the total cost of the given tour in g.

advalg.helpers module¶

advalg.helpers.choose(n: int, k: int) → int¶

Returns the binomial coefficient n choose k

advalg.helpers.combinations(items: Iterable[T_co], count: int) → Iterator[Tuple]¶

Returns all count-combinations of items as an iterator of tuples

advalg.helpers.haversine(lat1: float, lon1: float, lat2: float, lon2: float) → float¶

Returns the great-circle distance between points (lat1, lon1) and (lat2, lon2)

advalg.helpers.n_tuples(items: Iterable[T_co], count: int) → Iterator[Tuple]¶

Returns all count-tuples of of items as an iterator of tuples

advalg.helpers.permutations(items: Iterable[T_co], count: int) → Iterator[Tuple]¶

Returns all count-permutations of items as an iterator of tuples

advalg.helpers.subsets(items: Iterable[T_co]) → Iterator[Tuple]¶

Returns all subsets of items as an iterator of tuples

class advalg.lp.LP(variables: List[advalg.lp.Var], objective)¶

Bases: object

Represents a Linear Programming problem

Construct a LP problem with the given variables and objective function (Minimize or Maximize)

add_constraint(constraint) → None¶

Add a constrant to this problem

parse_output(output: str) → advalg.lp.LPResult¶
solve() → advalg.lp.LPResult¶

Attempt to solve the LP problem. Returns None if the problem is infeasible. Returns an LPResult if problem is feasible.

advalg.prim module¶

advalg.prim.mst(graph: advalg.graph.Graph) → advalg.graph.Graph¶

Computes a minimum spanning tree of the given graph using Prim’s algorithm. The MST is returned as a graph g.

advalg.sat_solver module¶

advalg.sat_solver.is_satisfiable(cnf: advalg.cnf.CNF) → bool¶

Is the given CNF formula satisfiable?

advalg.sat_solver.parse_clause(string: str)¶

Parse a CNF clause

advalg.sat_solver.parse_cnf(string: str) → advalg.cnf.CNF¶

Returns a CNF object from the given string representation

advalg.sat_solver.parse_output(out_file: str) → Tuple[bool, Dict[int, bool]]¶
advalg.sat_solver.solve(cnf: advalg.cnf.CNF) → Dict[int, int]¶

Returns a solution to cnf if it is satisfiable, otherwise None

advalg.sat_solver.to_cnf_format(cnf: advalg.cnf.CNF) → str¶

Returns a DIMACS CNF string representation of cnf

advalg.tests3 module¶

advalg.tests3.random_dnf(vars: int, clauses: int, clause_size: int) → advalg.dnf.DNF¶
advalg.tests3.results(counter: Callable[[advalg.dnf.DNF, int], float], dnf: advalg.dnf.DNF) → List[float]¶
advalg.tests3.test_dnf(counter: Callable[[advalg.dnf.DNF, int], float])¶

Tests the given counter function on 4 different DNF formulas. Plots the output of your implementation and compares with actual result.

advalg.tests4 module¶

advalg.tests4.test_tsp_approx(tsp_approx: Callable[[int, advalg.graph.Graph], List[int]]) → None¶

Tests the implementation of the 2-approximation for TSP

advalg.tests4.test_tsp_dp(tsp_dp: Callable[[int, advalg.graph.Graph], List[int]]) → None¶

Tests the implementation of the DP for TSP

advalg.tests4.test_vc_approx(vc_approx: Callable[[advalg.graph.Graph], Iterable[int]]) → None¶

Tests the implementation of a 2-approximation for vertex cover

Tests the implementation of inclusion-exclusion algorithm for hamiltonian cycles

Tests the implementation of the inclusion-exclusion algorithm for perfect matchings

Tests the reduction from vertex cover to SAT
